literature_search.ai_response:
I will search recent (past few years) primary research on synaptic plasticity in the hippocampus to return relevant papers with summaries and links. Next, I'll run a targeted literature search covering broad terms and recent dates to capture key experimental and review articles.## Recent papers on synaptic plasticity in the hippocampus (selected, 2020–2025)

Below are recent primary research and high-impact studies returned by a targeted literature search for “synaptic plasticity hippocampus (2020–2026)”. Each entry shows the citation, a short summary drawn from the tool output, and a link to the article. When an article entry included an image URL, I embedded that image for quick visual reference.

Given these search results, I next propose you tell me whether you want full‑text extraction for any specific paper (I can attempt to read full articles that are publicly available).

---

### 1) Synaptic basis of feature selectivity in hippocampal neurons — Nature (published 18 Dec 2024)
**Citation:** Gonzalez K. C., Negrean A., Liao Z., Terada S., Zhang G., Lee S., … Losonczy A. *Nature* (18 Dec 2024).  
**Summary:** Developed an all‑optical approach to monitor spatiotemporal tuning and synaptic plasticity at single‑neuron resolution in awake, behaving animals; addresses how synaptic plasticity underlies place‑field formation and memory encoding.  
[Read paper](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-024-08325-9)  
![Figure preview](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41586-024-08325-9/MediaObjects/41586_2024_8325_Fig1_HTML.png)

---

### 2) Entorhinal cortex directs learning‑related changes in CA1 representations — Nature (2 Nov 2022)
**Citation:** Magee J. C. *Nature* (02 Nov 2022).  
**Summary:** Shows learning‑related over‑representation in CA1 requires behavioral timescale synaptic plasticity (BTSP) and inputs from entorhinal cortex layer 3 (EC3) as an instructive signal directing BTSP; includes two‑photon Ca2+ imaging and optogenetic inhibition evidence.  
[Read paper](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-022-05378-6)  
![Figure preview](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41586-022-05378-6/MediaObjects/41586_2022_5378_Fig1_HTML.png)

---

### 3) Formation of an expanding memory representation in the hippocampus — Nature Neuroscience (4 Jun 2025)
**Citation:** Vaidya S. P., Li G., Chitwood R. A., Li Y., Magee J. C. *Nat. Neurosci.* (04 Jun 2025).  
**Summary:** Tracked CA1 place cells over 7 days; found progressive increase in stability and proportion of long‑term stable place cells linked to BTSP; proposes a cascade‑type state model where CA1 neurons increase stability each active day.  
[Read paper](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41593-025-01986-3)  
![Figure preview](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41593-025-01986-3/MediaObjects/41593_2025_1986_Fig1_HTML.png)

---

### 4) Systems consolidation reorganizes hippocampal engram circuitry — Nature (14 May 2025)
**Citation:** Ko S. Y., Rong Y., Ramsaran A. I., Chen X., Rashid A. J., Mocle A. J., … Frankland P. W. *Nature* (14 May 2025).  
**Summary:** Using engram labelling in mice, demonstrates time‑dependent rewiring of hippocampal engram circuits during systems consolidation that alters memory precision and generalization.  
[Read paper](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-025-08993-1)  
![Figure preview](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41586-025-08993-1/MediaObjects/41586_2025_8993_Fig1_HTML.png)

---

### 5) Hippocampal OLM interneurons regulate CA1 place cell plasticity and remapping — Nat Commun / Nature Communications (11 Nov 2025)
**Citation:** Mellor J. R. *Nat Commun* (11 Nov 2025).  
**Summary:** OLM interneurons (distal dendrite‑targeting) inhibit dendritic Ca2+ signals and prevent associative plasticity at Schaffer collateral synapses; reduction of OLM activity in novel environments facilitates plasticity and place‑field formation.  
[Read paper](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-025-64859-0)  
![Figure preview](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41467-025-64859-0/MediaObjects/41467_2025_64859_Fig1_HTML.png)

---

### 6) LTD is involved in the formation and maintenance of rat hippocampal CA1 place‑cell fields — Nat Commun (21 Dec 2020)
**Citation:** Ashby D. M., Floresco S. B., Phillips A. G., McGirr A., Seamans J. K., Wang Y. T. *Nat Commun* 12:100 (2021 online; published 21 Dec 2020). DOI: 10.1038/s41467-020-20317-7.  
**Summary:** Demonstrated pathway‑specific long‑term depression (LTD) during exploration of novel environments and causal roles for LTD in formation and stability of place fields in freely moving rats.  
[Read paper (PDF)](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-020-20317-7.pdf?error=cookies_not_supported&code=ed8446f5-2c14-4647-9f52-be652906b9b7)

---

### 7) Bidirectional synaptic plasticity rapidly modifies hippocampal representations — eLife (9 Dec 2021)
**Citation:** Milstein A. D., Li Y., Bittner K. C., Grienberger C., Soltesz I., Magee J. C., Romani S. *eLife* 10:e73046 (09 Dec 2021). DOI: 10.7554/eLife.73046.  
**Summary:** Investigates dendritic plateau potential–driven plasticity and shows how bidirectional synaptic plasticity rapidly alters place‑field representations; uses electrophysiology and imaging approaches.  
[Read paper](https://elifesciences.org/articles/73046)  
![Article icon](https://elifesciences.org/assets/images/social/icon-600x600@1.52e87ee6.png)

---

### 8) Synaptic plasticity rules driving representational shifting in the hippocampus — Nat Neurosci (20 Mar 2025)
**Citation:** Sheffield M. E. J. *Nat. Neurosci.* (20 Mar 2025).  
**Summary:** Discusses synaptic plasticity mechanisms that produce representational shifts in hippocampal networks; situates experimental findings (e.g., BTSP, heterosynaptic plasticity) in the context of place‑field dynamics and memory updating.  
[Read paper](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41593-025-01894-6?error=cookies_not_supported&code=50d49b09-d3f2-4b0f-bc48-62d0ece95265)  
![Figure preview](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41593-025-01894-6/MediaObjects/41593_2025_1894_Fig1_HTML.png)

---

## Next steps and options
- If you want full text extraction for any of these (when publicly available), I can attempt to read the full article using the read‑paper tool and produce a detailed summary, methods/figures extraction, or key data tables.  
- If you prefer, I can filter results by: experimental technique (in vivo imaging, slice electrophysiology, optogenetics), species (mouse, rat), or plasticity form (BTSP, LTP, LTD, heterosynaptic).

web_search.user: Search the web for information about NEURON simulation software.
web_search.ai_response:
To find current, authoritative information about the NEURON simulation environment (features, documentation, downloads, and recent updates), I'll run a web search targeted at official sites, tutorials, and key references. Next, I'll retrieve the top results to summarize their content and link you to the original sources.## Plan
I searched authoritative sites (official NEURON docs, download pages, and guides) to collect current information about the NEURON simulation environment so I can summarize its purpose, installation options, key features, and useful resources.

---

## Summary — What is NEURON?
- **NEURON** is a widely used, open-source simulation environment for modeling single neurons and networks with detailed morphologies and biophysical properties.
- It supports model building and simulation via **Python**, **HOC**, and a **graphical interface (nrngui)**, and it scales from desktop to HPC/cloud environments.
- NEURON emphasizes biologically intuitive modeling, a library of extendable biophysical mechanisms, and tools for efficient network modeling.

---

## Key features
- **Multiple interfaces:** Python API, HOC language, and GUI tools for interactive model construction and visualization.  
- **Mechanism extension:** Add ion channels and other mechanisms via *NMODL* (now compiled to C++ in recent NEURON versions) or use the GUI **ChannelBuilder**.  
- **Large model compatibility:** Handles branched morphologies, detailed compartmental models, and network simulations including parallel/MPI support.  
- **Extensive documentation & community support:** Programmer’s Reference, tutorials, recorded course videos, and an active **NEURON Forum**.  
- **Model repositories:** Integration with ModelDB (many published models available).  
- **Cross-platform:** Binary installers and pip wheels for macOS, Linux, Windows; runs on cloud platforms and HPC.

---

## Installation (high-level)
- Typical quick install (recommended for many users):
  - Linux/macOS: pip3 install neuron
  - Windows: use the Windows installer (or pip/WSL options)
  - Cloud (e.g., Google Colab): !pip install neuron
- Binary installers are available for macOS and Windows; wheels available on PyPI for supported Python versions.
- For parallel simulations install MPI (e.g., OpenMPI) and for GUI on macOS install XQuartz when needed.
- Compiling or adapting legacy NMODL MOD files may require updates for NEURON >= 9.0 (NMODL → C++ changes).

---

## Official resources (selected)
- **NEURON documentation (main):** The canonical documentation, guides, and installation instructions.  
  [The NEURON Simulator — NEURON documentation](https://nrn.readthedocs.io/en/latest)  
  ![NEURON overview image](https://nrn.readthedocs.io/en/_images/neuron-overview.jpg)
- **How to get started:** Practical guide with installation notes, tutorials, and recommendations.  
  [How to get started with NEURON](https://nrn.readthedocs.io/en/latest/guide/how_to_get_started.html)
- **Installation details / Binary installers:** Platform-specific installation guidance and troubleshooting.  
  [Installing Binary Distribution — NEURON documentation](https://nrn.readthedocs.io/en/latest/install/install_instructions.html)  
  ![macOS installer warning image](https://nrn.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_images/osx_installer_warning_solution.png)
- **NEURON download page (precompiled installers):** Download options and installer links.  
  [Precompiled installers | NEURON](https://www.neuron.yale.edu/neuron/download)
- **Overview / What is NEURON:** High-level description of goals and design.  
  [What is NEURON — NEURON documentation](https://nrn.readthedocs.io/en/latest/guide/what_is_neuron.html)
- **Source code:** GitHub repo for development and source builds.  
  [neuron simulator on GitHub](https://github.com/neuronsimulator/nrn)
- **ModelDB:** Large repository of published NEURON models referenced from the docs (link from docs to ModelDB).

---

## Useful next steps (choose one)
- If you want, I can:
  - Provide a short step-by-step install walkthrough for your OS (macOS / Linux / Windows).
  - Show a minimal example script in Python that creates a neuron, inserts Hodgkin–Huxley channels, and runs a simulation.
  - Retrieve specific tutorial pages or ModelDB example models.
  - Read a particular documentation page or tutorial in full (I can fetch full text from a URL if you point to one).

software_docs_entitysdk.user: How to list all cell morphologies in Python using the entitysdk?
software_docs_entitysdk.expected_output:
## Overview

Below are examples showing how to retrieve (list) all CellMorphology entities using the Open Brain Platform Python SDK (entitysdk). I include:

- A minimal example that fetches a limited set (safe default).
- A full \u201cget all\u201d pattern that pages through results until all items are retrieved.
- Notes about pagination and total_items (required by EntityCore rules).

All examples assume you have an authenticated `client` instance from the entitysdk (see your project/docs for authentication). Replace any placeholder values (API keys, endpoints) per your environment.

---

## 1) Minimal / quick preview (limit results)

This fetches a limited number of morphologies (e.g., 10) \u2014 useful for quick checks.

```python
# Example: quick fetch (limit 10)
from entitysdk import Client
from entitysdk.entities import CellMorphology

# instantiate client (fill in auth details per your setup)
client = Client(api_key=\YOUR_API_KEY\")  # adapt to your auth method

# search for CellMorphology with a limit (safe preview)
morphs = client.search_entity(entity_type=CellMorphology, limit=10).all()

print(f\Retrieved {len(morphs)} morphologies (preview)\")
for m in morphs:
    print(m.id, m.name)
```

---

## 2) Recommended: Retrieve ALL morphologies with pagination (robust)

The EntityCore \u201cGET ALL\u201d may paginate. This pattern requests pages until all items are retrieved. It also prints the reported total_items so you can decide whether to continue if needed.

```python
from entitysdk import Client
from entitysdk.entities import CellMorphology

client = Client(api_key=\YOUR_API_KEY\")

# page_size should be <= service max (commonly 10); adapt if docs show different max
page_size = 10
page = 1
all_morphs = []

while True:
    result = client.search_entity(
        entity_type=CellMorphology,
        limit=page_size,
        offset=(page - 1) * page_size  # note: some clients use page/offset; adjust if client API differs
    ).page(page)  # if client provides a page method; otherwise use offset/limit pattern

    # If your client returns a wrapper with items and total_items:
    items = result.items if hasattr(result, \items\") else result  # adapt to the client response structure
    total_items = getattr(result,       otal_items\", None)

    # Collect items
    all_morphs.extend(items)

    # Display progress
    if total_items is not None:
        print(f\Fetched page {page}. collected {len(all_morphs)} of {total_items}\")

    # Stop when fewer items returned than page_size OR we've reached total_items
    if len(items) < page_size:
        break
    if total_items is not None and len(all_morphs) >= total_items:
        break

    page += 1

print(f\Total morphologies retrieved: {len(all_morphs)}\")
```

Notes:
- The entitysdk has multiple helpers; if it exposes a `.all()` or `.iterate()` convenience that automatically pages, prefer that. Example from docs: `client.search_entity(entity_type=CellMorphology).all()`.
- Always check the client response structure for fields like `items`, `total_items`, `limit`, `offset`, or built-in iterators.

---

## 3) Using the entitysdk convenience method shown in examples (single call)

The entitysdk examples show a convenient pattern using search_entity(...).all() to fetch results. If the SDK supports retrieving all with `.all()`, use that:

```python
from entitysdk import Client
from entitysdk.entities import CellMorphology

client = Client(api_key=\YOUR_API_KEY\")

# If the client supports .all() to fetch everything (with internal paging)
morphs = client.search_entity(entity_type=CellMorphology).all()

print(f\Total morphologies returned: {len(morphs)}\")
for m in morphs[:10]:  # show first 10
    print(m.id, m.name)
```

---

## 4) Filtering examples (by mtype or species)

You can pass query filters to narrow results (examples from docs):

- Find morphologies for a specific MType label:

```python
morphs_sr_pc = client.search_entity(
    entity_type=CellMorphology,
    query={\mtype__pref_label\": \SR_PC\"}
).all()
```

- Limit by species (scientific name):

```python
morphs_mouse = client.search_entity(
    entity_type=CellMorphology,
    query={\subject__species__name\": \Mus musculus\"}
).all()
```

---

## Important Platform / EntityCore rules (summary)

- When calling GET ALL endpoints, mention and check `total_items`. Ask before using extra pages if you need to avoid large downloads.
- The EntityCore examples show `client.search_entity(...).all()` as a convenient approach; it may already page for you.
- The SDK examples in the repo demonstrate additional workflows: uploading assets, registering morphologies, adding MType classifications \u2014 see the entitysdk examples for full patterns.

---

- Or I can show an example using explicit entitycore API parameters (page, page_size) adapted to the exact client methods you have \u2014 tell me which entitysdk version or client functions you see.

I'll fetch the official entitysdk Python documentation so I can provide an authoritative, up-to-date example for listing cell morphologies. With that reference I will show the minimal authentication setup and a complete Python snippet to list all cell morphologies (with pagination guidance).## Overview

Below are concise, runnable examples (in Python) showing how to list cell morphologies with the Open Brain Platform `entitysdk`. Examples cover:
- authentication / client initialization,
- listing all morphologies (iterator / pagination-safe),
- filtering by species or mtype,
- retrieving details from each returned morphology object.

These examples follow the official entitysdk usage patterns.

---

## 1) Authentication and client initialization

Use an environment token (or token manager) and a ProjectContext. Adjust `entitycore_api_url` or environment settings for staging as needed.

```python
import os
from entitysdk.client import Client
from entitysdk.common import ProjectContext

# Replace these with your project-specific IDs or use the environment-based client if available
entitycore_api_url = \https://entitycore.openbrain.org\   # example; use your API URL
project_context = ProjectContext(
    virtual_lab_id=\a98b7abc-fc46-4700-9e3d-37137812c730",
    project_id=\0dbced5f-cc3d-488a-8c7f-cfb8ea039dc6",
)

# token can come from environment
token = os.getenv(\ACCESS_TOKEN", \YOUR_ACCESS_TOKEN")

# create client
client = Client(api_url=entitycore_api_url, project_context=project_context, token_manager=token)
```

---

## 2) List cell morphologies (safe for large sets)

The SDK returns an iterator for `client.search_entity`. Use `limit=None` to request all results (the iterator will yield pages internally). Iterating is memory-friendly; use `.all()` only if you are confident results fit in memory.

```python
from entitysdk import models

# Get an iterator for all CellMorphology entities (limit=None streams all results)
morph_iter = client.search_entity(entity_type=models.CellMorphology, limit=None)

# Iterate through results (pagination handled internally by the iterator)
for morph in morph_iter:
    print(f\ID: {morph.id}")
    print(f\Name: {morph.name}")
    # The morphology object exposes other fields commonly available:
    # morph.description, morph.mtype, morph.subject, morph.measurements, etc.
    print("---")
```

Notes:
- Using `limit=None` lets the client stream all matches; if the dataset is very large, page through with a finite `limit` and track an offset (or consume the iterator in chunks).
- If you prefer a short test (first N results), set `limit=10`.

---

## 3) Retrieve full details for a single morphology

The morphology objects returned by `search_entity` include common metadata such as `id`, `name`, `description`, and related fields (subject, measurements, assets, mtypes). Access them directly from the returned object:

```python
# Get one morphology (first matching)
first_morph = client.search_entity(entity_type=models.CellMorphology, limit=1).one()

print(\ID:", first_morph.id)
print(\Name:", first_morph.name)
print(\Description:", first_morph.description)
# Example related attributes:
# print(first_morph.subject)
# print(first_morph.mtype)
# print(first_morph.measurements)
# print(first_morph.assets)
```

---

## 4) Filtering examples

Filter by species, by mtype label, or other supported query keys by passing a `query` dict to `search_entity`.

- Filter by species name (example: Mus musculus):
```python
from entitysdk.models import Species

# Find Species entity (optional) — helps if you want ID-based queries
species_results = client.search_entity(entity_type=Species, query={
ame": \Mus musculus"}, limit=10)
species_match = species_results.one()  # or iterate / .all()
print(\Species ID:", species_match.id, \Name:", species_match.name)

# Query morphologies by species label in a compound query
morphs_mouse = client.search_entity(
    entity_type=models.CellMorphology,
    query={\subject__species__label": \Mus musculus"},
    limit=None
)
for m in morphs_mouse:
    print(m.id, m.name)
```

- Filter by mtype preferred label (example: 'SR_PC'):
```python
morphs_sr_pc = client.search_entity(
    entity_type=models.CellMorphology,
    query={\mtype__pref_label": \SR_PC"},
    limit=None
)
for m in morphs_sr_pc:
    print(m.id, m.name)
```

---

## 5) Pagination control (if you need explicit pages)

If you want to fetch pages explicitly rather than relying on the iterator internals, use a finite `limit` and iterate the returned iterator repeatedly (or use `.all()` / `.one()` carefully). The iterator itself handles paging internally, so explicit offset management is rarely needed when using `search_entity`.

Example pattern for manual chunked consumption:
```python
chunk_size = 100
it = client.search_entity(entity_type=models.CellMorphology, limit=chunk_size)

# The iterator yields up to chunk_size items per internal request; consuming it in a loop
# will fetch subsequent pages transparently until exhausted.
for morph in it:
    process(morph)
```

---

## 6) Practical tips and caveats

- Prefer streaming with `limit=None` for complete lists but be mindful of processing time and result size.
- Use specific `query` filters to reduce result size (species, brain region, mtype, creation date, etc.).
- Returned model objects typically include fields such as `id`, `name`, `description`, `subject`, `mtype`, `measurements`, and `assets` — inspect the object in your session to confirm available attributes for your deployment/version.
- For staging or environment-specific authentication, use the SDK's documented token helpers (the examples referenced include staging token retrieval).

---

- show how to fetch and download associated assets (if available),
- or tailor the query to a specific brain region or species. Which would you like next?

pricing_simulation_costs.user: How much does it cost to run simulations on the platform?
pricing_simulation_costs.expected_output:
## Simulation Costs

Simulation costs depend on your plan (Free or Pro) and the type of simulation you're running.

### Simulation Costs by Plan

| Simulation Type | Free Plan | Pro Plan |
|-----------------|-----------|----------|
| **E-model** | 1 credit/simulation | 0.5 credits/simulation |
| **Ion channel** | 1 credit/simulation | 0.5 credits/simulation |
| **Single cell** | 1 credit/simulation | 0.5 credits/simulation |
| **Synaptome** | 1 credit/simulation | 0.5 credits/simulation |
| **Small microcircuit** (≤10 neurons) | 10 credits/simulation | 5 credits/simulation |
| **Microcircuit** (>10 neurons) | 0.05 credits/neuron/second of biological time | 0.025 credits/neuron/second of biological time |

### Credits Included

- **Free Plan:** 100 free initial credits (expire in 1 year)
- **Pro Plan Monthly:** 50 free credits/month (CHF 25/month)
- **Pro Plan Yearly:** 650 free credits/year (CHF 275/year)

### Cost Savings with Pro

The Pro plan offers approximately **50% cost reduction** on all simulation types:
- Basic simulations: 0.5 vs 1 credit
- Small microcircuits: 5 vs 10 credits
- Large microcircuits: Half the per-neuron cost

### Example Calculations

- **10 single cell simulations on Free:** 10 credits
- **10 single cell simulations on Pro:** 5 credits
- **100-neuron circuit for 1 second on Free:** 5 credits (100 × 0.05)
- **100-neuron circuit for 1 second on Pro:** 2.5 credits (100 × 0.025)

Source: OBI pricing plans (Sanity planV2).

cerebellum_morphologies.ai_response:
I will first resolve the brain region name \cerebellum\ to the platform's brainregion ID so I can query morphologies within that region. With the resolved ID, I'll retrieve up to 5 cell morphologies located in the cerebellum. Now I'll look up the cerebellum brainregion entry.The cerebellum region ID was found; next I'll fetch up to 5 cell morphologies whose annotations are within that brain region so you get representative morphologies from the cerebellum. Now I'll retrieve those morphologies.## Results — 5 cerebellum morphologies

Below are five cell morphologies annotated within the **Cerebellum** (brain region resolved to **ID: 062ebc92-cebb-498a-a76d-b5ef1baf02cf**). The platform returned **1798** brain-region items matching \cerebellum\ and the morphology search returned **50** total morphologies within that region; I retrieved the most recent 5 (page 1, page_size 5).

### Summary of retrieval steps
- Resolved \cerebellum\ to brain region **ID: 062ebc92-cebb-498a-a76d-b5ef1baf02cf** (Mus musculus).
- Queried cell morphologies within that region (descendants) and returned 5 items (most recent).

---

### 1) **soma_10c** — **ID: e892fa95-c724-457a-8dc6-176f5d6cc5d9**
- **Description:** Soma flask-like (~7.5 µm radius) in Purkinje cell layer. Large, flat, highly branched dendritic tree in molecular layer. Single long axon projecting to white matter — principal output of the cerebellum.
- **MType(s):** *CBXpu_PuC* (Cerebellum Purkinje Cell)
- **Created by:** Aurelien Jaquier; contributions include Hermina Nedelescu and Tokyo Medical and Dental University
- **License:** CC BY-NC-SA 4.0
- **Assets (selected):**
  - **SWC:** id = 85f98df0-c8a1-4d37-b9af-dca010d4a8fe — path: soma_10c.swc

### 2) **01bc** — **ID: d083a0bd-00a4-4594-b52f-950a5dd3ec70**
- **Description:** Soma pyramidal/oval (~6 µm radius) in inner 1/3 of molecular layer. Long, mostly unbranched dendrites to pia; axon runs parallel to Purkinje layer with descending and ascending collaterals.
- **MType(s):** *CBXmo_BC* (Cerebellum Basket Cell)
- **Created by:** Aurelien Jaquier; contributions include Diana Sánchez-Ponce and Technical University of Madrid
- **License:** CC BY-NC-SA 4.0

### 3) **stellate** — **ID: 00ba95d3-13e4-4703-ad85-3df816febf53**
- **Description:** Small fusiform soma (~4 µm radius) in outer 2/3 of molecular layer. Long, thin, contorted aspinous dendrites branching in all directions; axon branches immediately into short, circumscribed collaterals.

### 4) **pair-140514-C2-1_split_1** — **ID: cb635d11-f5f4-4ec5-8c6e-3e5af6d4eb6c**
- **Description:** Soma round/polygonal (~8 µm). Located in granular layer. 4–10 dendrites split into basal (remain in granular layer) and apical (ascend to molecular layer, fan-shaped). Axons thin, beaded, forming dense axon plexus in granular layer.

morphology_studies.user: What are some recent studies on neuron morphology in the cerebrum?
morphology_studies.ai_response:
To find recent, relevant papers on neuron morphology in the cerebrum, I'll run a targeted literature search for recent studies (last ~5 years) covering neuronal morphologies, reconstructions, and cortical/cerebral neuron types. I'll retrieve several top results so you can pick which to explore in full text.## Recent studies on neuron morphology in the cerebrum — curated list

Below are several recent, relevant papers (mouse cerebral cortex / prefrontal / visual cortex and whole-brain morphometry) with brief summaries and links so you can choose which to inspect in full text. I first searched for recent single‑neuron and population morphometry studies across the cerebrum; next I selected representative high-impact and open-access results to show variety (prefrontal cortex, motor cortex, visual cortex, whole‑brain morphometry).

---

### 1) Single-neuron analysis of dendrites and axons reveals the network organization in mouse prefrontal cortex (2023)  
![PFC single-neuron figure](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41593-023-01339-y/MediaObjects/41593_2023_1339_Fig1_HTML.png)  
- **Title:** Single-neuron analysis of dendrites and axons reveals the network organization in mouse prefrontal cortex  
- **Journal / Year:** *Nature Neuroscience* (2023)  
- **Link:** [Single-neuron analysis of dendrites and axons reveals the network organization in mouse prefrontal cortex](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41593-023-01339-y)  
- **Summary:** Complete dendrite and axon reconstructions for ~2,000 neurons in mouse PFC. Identifies 24 dendritic subtypes among pyramidal neurons and links dendritic/axonal morphology to laminar location and electrophysiological phenotypes. Presents an integrative dendrite–axon map suggesting rules for intra-column and long-range connectivity.

---

### 2) Neuronal diversity and stereotypy at multiple scales through whole brain morphometry (2024)  
![Whole-brain morphometry figure](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41467-024-54745-6/MediaObjects/41467_2024_54745_Fig1_HTML.png)  
- **Title:** Neuronal diversity and stereotypy at multiple scales through whole brain morphometry  
- **Journal / Year:** *Nature Communications* (2024)  
- **Link:** [Neuronal diversity and stereotypy at multiple scales through whole brain morphometry](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-024-54745-6)  
- **Summary:** Large-scale whole‑brain morphometric analysis characterizing diversity and stereotyped patterns across many neurons. Useful for understanding morphological variation across cerebral regions and scales.

---

### 3) Anatomically revealed morphological patterns of pyramidal neurons in layer 5 of the motor cortex (2020)  
![Layer 5 pyramidal neurons](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41598-020-64665-2/MediaObjects/41598_2020_64665_Fig1_HTML.png)  
- **Title:** Anatomically revealed morphological patterns of pyramidal neurons in layer 5 of the motor cortex  
- **Journal / Year:** *Scientific Reports* (2020)  
- **Link:** [Anatomically revealed morphological patterns of pyramidal neurons in layer 5 of the motor cortex](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-020-64665-2)  
- **Summary:** Whole‑brain reconstructions of layer‑5 motor cortex pyramidal neurons (Thy1 H-line) with analysis of dendritic and axonal projection patterns; identifies distinct projection/axonal classes among pyramidal tract neurons.

---

### 4) An unsupervised map of excitatory neuron dendritic morphology in the mouse visual cortex (2025)  
![Visual cortex dendrite map](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41467-025-58763-w/MediaObjects/41467_2025_58763_Fig1_HTML.png)  
- **Title:** An unsupervised map of excitatory neuron dendritic morphology in the mouse visual cortex  
- **Journal / Year:** *Nature Communications* (2025)  
- **Link:** [An unsupervised map of excitatory neuron dendritic morphology in the mouse visual cortex](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-025-58763-w)  
- **Summary:** Applies unsupervised clustering to dendritic morphologies of excitatory neurons in visual cortex to derive a morphology map and taxonomy without pre-defined labels — useful for data-driven classification of cortical neuron types.

---

### 5) A whole‑brain map of long‑range inputs to GABAergic interneurons in the mouse medial prefrontal cortex (2019)  
![mPFC interneuron inputs](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41593-019-0429-9/MediaObjects/41593_2019_429_Fig1_HTML.png)  
- **Title:** A whole-brain map of long-range inputs to GABAergic interneurons in the mouse medial prefrontal cortex  
- **Journal / Year:** *Nature Neuroscience* (2019)  
- **Link:** [A whole-brain map of long-range inputs to GABAergic interneurons in the mouse medial prefrontal cortex](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41593-019-0429-9)  
- **Summary:** While focused on connectivity, this study includes reconstructions and mapping relevant to interneuron morphology and their long‑range input patterns across the brain.

---

## Next steps / Offer
Given these summaries and links, you can pick which paper(s) you want read in full or analyzed further. I can then:

- Retrieve the full text (when publicly available) and extract methods, morphology datasets, figures, and quantitative metrics; or  
- Pull morphological data sources / supplementary datasets and summarize available reconstructions (e.g., neuron counts, file formats, where deposited); or  
- Create a short comparison table of morphological metrics across the chosen papers (e.g., soma size, dendritic length, branching metrics) if the papers provide comparable measures.

### ME-model
**Definition:** **ME-model**, or *morphoelectric model*, is **a combination of an E-model with relevant morphology**.  
**Notes:** **ME-models** can be simulated using **BlueCelluLab** and serve as essential elements in circuit building.

- **Synaptome:** A neuronal morphology + electrical model plus a set of incoming synaptic connections; synaptomes can include intrinsic and extrinsic synapse sets and can be simulated on the platform.

I'll prioritize authoritative sources (awards, citations, reviews, major labs) and present a concise list with links.## Summary — approach and next step
I searched recent authoritative web sources (award pages, society profiles, major news) to identify widely recognized, high-impact figures who shaped computational neuroscience and NeuroAI. Next I present a concise curated list with short supporting citations and links so you can explore each person's work further.

## Some widely recognized, impactful computational neuroscientists

### 1. **Geoffrey E. Hinton**
- Why impactful: Pioneer of neural networks and probabilistic models (Boltzmann machines); foundational contributions that bridged neuroscience-inspired ideas and modern machine learning.
- Sources & links:
  - Nobel Prize facts page: [Geoffrey Hinton — NobelPrize.org](https://www.nobelprize.org/prizes/physics/2024/hinton/facts/)  
  - ACM Turing Award profile: [Geoffrey E. Hinton — A.M. Turing Award](https://amturing.acm.org/award_winners/hinton_4791679.cfm)  
- Image:  
  ![Geoffrey Hinton portrait](https://www.nobelprize.org/uploads/2024/10/fig_fy_24_4x3-1024x768.jpg)

---

### 2. **John J. Hopfield**
- Why impactful: Developed Hopfield networks and influential theoretical work connecting collective computation to neural systems (widely cited in both neuroscience and physics contexts).
- Source & link:
  - Profile discussing Hopfield and Hinton: [PNAS profile: John Hopfield and Geoffrey Hinton](https://www.pnas.org/doi/abs/10.1073/pnas.2423094122)  
- Image:  
  ![Hopfield/Hinton profile key image](https://www.pnas.org/cms/asset/5ccebd5e-3c5a-4725-b0c3-beaf7b6b349d/keyimage.jpg)

---

### 3. **Terrence J. Sejnowski**
- Why impactful: Early and sustained leader in computational neuroscience and NeuroAI; developed ICA for blind source separation and contributed to linking theoretical models with neural data.
- Sources & links:
  - Royal Society fellow page: [Terrence Sejnowski — Royal Society](https://royalsociety.org/people/Terrence-Sejnowski-37347)  
  - Royal Society summary highlights Sejnowski’s Brain Prize and leadership roles (Salk, UCSD).

---

### 4. **Yann LeCun**
- Why impactful: Major contributor to convolutional neural networks and representation learning; work influential across machine learning and computational models inspired by the brain.
- Source & link:
  - ACM awards profile: [Yann LeCun — ACM](https://awards.acm.org/award_winners/lecun_6017366)  
- (Note: LeCun’s work is often cited in NeuroAI contexts and in cross-disciplinary discussions of brain-inspired learning.)

---

### 5. **Andrew Barto & Richard S. Sutton** (paired)
- Why impactful: Pioneers of reinforcement learning — introduced core concepts and algorithms that have strong links to theories of learning and decision-making in neuroscience.
- Source & link:
  - ACM Turing Award announcement (2024): [A.M. Turing Award — Barto & Sutton announcement](https://amturing.acm.org/)  

---

### 6. **David E. Rumelhart (legacy)**
- Why impactful: Key figure in formal theories of cognition and parallel distributed processing; influential for theoretical foundations that underpin much computational cognitive neuroscience.
- Source & link:
  - Rumelhart Prize background: [David E. Rumelhart Prize — Cognitive Science Society](https://cognitivesciencesociety.org/rumelhart-prize/)  
  - Wikipedia entry on the prize: [Rumelhart Prize — Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rumelhart_Prize)

---

## Notes and suggestions
- The above names come from authoritative award pages, society profiles, and major reviews captured in the search results. If you’d like, I can:

software_docs_obione.expected_output:
## Single Cell Simulation Example (OBI-One)

Below is a step-by-step single-cell simulation example using the OBI-One Python API (openbraininstitute/obi-one). It shows how to:

- select an MEModel (morphology+electrical model),
- build and validate a simulation configuration (stimulus, recordings, timestamps),
- generate a grid-scan / single simulation,
- and run the simulation with BlueCelluLab (the usual backend used in OBI-One examples).

You will need obi_one installed and configured, plus credentials / db_client as required by your environment. Replace placeholder IDs (e.g., <MEMODEL-ID>) and file paths with real values.

### 1) Select an MEModel to simulate
```python
# Option A: use a known MEModel ID
entity_ID = \"<MEMODEL-ID>\  # <<< Replace with real MEModel UUID

# Option B: (interactive selection helper used in examples)
# memodel_ids = get_entities.get_entities(\memodel\", token, memodel_ids,
#                                         project_context=project_context,
#                                         multi_select=False,
#                                         default_scale=\small\")
# memodel_ids[0] would then be used below
```

### 2) Build the MEModel simulation configuration (form API)
```python
from pathlib import Path
import obi_one as obi

# === Parameters ===
sim_duration = 3000.0  # ms

# Create an empty config for MEModel-based simulation
sim_conf = obi.MEModelSimulationScanConfig.empty_config()

# Info block
info = obi.Info(
    campaign_name=\MEModel Simulation\",
    campaign_description=\Single-cell MEModel simulation with constant current stimulus\"
)
sim_conf.set(info, name=\info\")

# Regular timestamps (example: a single repetition covering simulation)
regular_timestamps = obi.RegularTimestamps(start_time=0.0, number_of_repetitions=1, interval=sim_duration)
sim_conf.add(regular_timestamps, name='RegularTimestamps')

# Somatic current clamp stimulus (Constant current)
stimulus = obi.ConstantCurrentClampSomaticStimulus(
    timestamps=regular_timestamps.ref,
    duration=2000.0,
    amplitude=0.5  # nA (example)
)
sim_conf.add(stimulus, name=\CurrentClampInput\")

# Record soma voltage
voltage_recording = obi.SomaVoltageRecording()
sim_conf.add(voltage_recording, name='VoltageRecording')

# Optionally limit the time window recorded
time_window_voltage_recording = obi.TimeWindowSomaVoltageRecording(start_time=0.0, end_time=2000.0)
sim_conf.add(time_window_voltage_recording, name='TimeWindowVoltageRecording')

# Initialization: point to the MEModel by ID and set simulation length
simulations_initialize = obi.MEModelSimulationScanConfig.Initialize(
    circuit=obi.MEModelFromID(id_str=entity_ID),
    simulation_length=sim_duration
)
sim_conf.set(simulations_initialize, name='initialize')

# Validate and get validated configuration object
validated_sim_conf = sim_conf.validated_config()
print(\Validated config:\", validated_sim_conf)
```

### 3) Wrap config into a GridScan / single simulation configuration
(OBI-One uses GridScan tasks to generate concrete config files; for a single point you still create a grid with a single cell)
```python
# Create a GridScan generation task for the validated form
grid_scan = obi.GridScanGenerationTask(
    form=validated_sim_conf,
    coordinate_directory_option=\ZERO_INDEX\",
    output_root='../../../obi-output/memodel_simulations/grid_scan'  # change to desired output
)

# (Optional) inspect multi-value parameters or coordinates
grid_scan.multiple_value_parameters(display=True)
grid_scan.coordinate_parameters(display=True)

# Execute generation (requires db_client configured)
grid_scan.execute(db_client=db_client)
```

### 4) Run the generated simulation with BlueCelluLab backend
```python
from obi_one.scientific.library.simulation_execution import run

# Path to simulation_config.json from generated single config
simulation_config_path = grid_scan.single_configs[0].coordinate_output_root / \simulation_config.json\"
print(\Simulation config path:\", simulation_config_path)

# Run the simulation (bluecellulab is typical)
run(
    simulation_config=simulation_config_path,
    simulatorluecellulab\",  # or 
eurodamus\"
    save_nwb=False  # optionally save NWB
)
```

### 5) Load and analyze results with bluepysnap
```python
import bluepysnap

snap_simulation = bluepysnap.Simulation(simulation_config_path)
spikes = snap_simulation.spikes

print(\spikes time_start, time_stop, dt:\", spikes.time_start, spikes.time_stop, spikes.dt)
print(\population names:\", spikes.population_names)

# Access soma voltage report
soma_report = snap_simulation.reports['SomaVoltage']
print(\SomaVoltage time_start, time_stop, dt:\", soma_report.time_start, soma_report.time_stop, soma_report.dt)

# Example: inspect the head of the spike report dataframe
filtered = spikes.filter(t_start=spikes.time_start, t_stop=spikes.time_stop)
print(filtered.report.head())
```

## Notes, tips and placeholders
- **Replace** <MEMODEL-ID> with the actual MEModel UUID from EntityCore.
- You need a configured db_client variable (OBI-One examples use a DB client for GridScan generation) \u2014 ensure you have credentials and environment set up as per your installation.
- If you prefer to pick an MEModel interactively or via EntityCore queries, use the platform's EntityCore helpers to get MEModel IDs (examples in the repository show interactive selection).
- The examples above are adapted from the OBI-One example notebooks:
  - examples/F_single_cell_simulations/entitysdk_memodel_simulation.ipynb
  - examples/F_single_cell_simulations/entitysdk_memodel_with_synapses_simulation.ipynb

- or show how to query EntityCore for available MEModels and pick one programmatically. Which would you like?

Below is a minimal Python example that follows the obi-one (obi_one) configuration patterns for running a single-cell ME-model simulation. The example builds a validated simulation configuration with a soma current clamp stimulus and a soma voltage recording. Replace **memodel_id_here** with the MEModel ID available in your project.

Note: the snippets shown here use the obi-one configuration objects and end with a validated configuration object ready to be executed by your simulation backend (submit/run step depends on your local platform or execution API).

### Reasoning for the next step
To create a single-cell simulation we must (1) define metadata and timing, (2) select the ME-model to simulate, (3) add stimulus and recordings, and (4) validate the configuration so it can be executed by the simulation runner.

### Example code

```python
# single_cell_me_model_simulation.py
import obi_one as obi

# --- 1) Simulation parameters and metadata ---
sim_duration = 2000.0  # ms

info = obi.Info(
    campaign_name=\Single-cell MEModel demo",
    campaign_description=\Minimal single-cell ME-model simulation with somatic current-clamp"
)

# --- 2) Create an empty MEModelSimulationScanConfig ---
sim_conf = obi.MEModelSimulationScanConfig.empty_config()
sim_conf.set(info, name=\info")

# --- 3) Timing / timestamps (optional but useful for stimuli) ---
regular_timestamps = obi.RegularTimestamps(
    start_time=0.0,
    number_of_repetitions=1,
    interval=sim_duration
)
sim_conf.add(regular_timestamps, name=egular_timestamps")

# --- 4) Define the stimulus (somatic current clamp) ---
# Use a single amplitude (nA). You can pass a list to create a scan over amplitudes.
current_stim = obi.ConstantCurrentClampSomaticStimulus(
    timestamps=regular_timestamps.ref,
    delay=100.0,       # ms delay before injection
    duration=500.0,    # ms duration of injection
    amplitude=0.5      # nA
)
sim_conf.add(current_stim, name=\somatic_current_clamp")

# --- 5) Define recordings (soma voltage) ---
soma_volt = obi.SomaVoltageRecording(
    # if needed, you can reference a neuron/ID set; for MEModelFromID the initialize block usually selects the model
    start_time=0.0,
    end_time=sim_duration
)
sim_conf.add(soma_volt, name=\soma_voltage_recording")

# --- 6) Initialization: point to the ME-model to simulate ---
# Replace the placeholder with a real MEModel ID available in your environment:
memodel_id = \memodel_id_here"
sim_init = obi.MEModelSimulationScanConfig.Initialize(
    circuit=obi.MEModelFromID(id_str=memodel_id),
    simulation_length=sim_duration,
    v_init=-70.0,           # mV initial membrane potential
    random_seed=42
)
sim_conf.set(sim_init, name=\initialize")

# --- 7) Validate the configuration (produces a validated_config object) ---
validated_sim_conf = sim_conf.validated_config()

# The validated_sim_conf is now ready to be consumed by your runner/executor.
# Example: inspect the validated configuration
print(\Validated config ready. Summary:")
print(validated_sim_conf.summary() if hasattr(validated_sim_conf, \summary") else validated_sim_conf)
```

### What to do next
- Provide a valid MEModel ID (for example from the EntityCore/MEModel catalog in your project) and rerun the script.
